title-group.article-title: Clinical assessment of calcium phosphate cement to treat tibial plateau fractures

abstract.p: The aim of this study was to examine histological changes in bone morphology after surgical treatment of tibial plateau fractures using calcium phosphate cement as a substitute for autologous bone grafting. A total of 42 patients with tibial plateau fractures were treated with open reduction, internal fixation, and calcium phosphate cement. A further 34 control patients underwent open reduction and internal fixation. Bone samples for histology were obtained during the surgery. Bone healing and functional recovery were assessed. Bone cell counts were significantly higher in samples obtained during the second surgery (81.2) compared with the first surgery (45.4, p < 0.001). Bone healing scores significantly increased with time after surgery (p < 0.001). Mean Hospital for Special Surgery knee scores were rated “good” for both the calcium phosphate cement group (82.3) and control group (79.4) in 12 months, and were not significantly different between groups. Histological examination of samples obtained during the second surgery revealed well-arranged trabeculae, in addition to new bone and blood vessel formation. These histological, radiological, and functional findings suggest that calcium phosphate cement may be an effective substitute for autologous bone grafting to treat tibial plateau fractures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Tibial plateau fractures are relatively common, particularly in the elderly. As the tibia is a weight-bearing bone, restoration of the tibial plateau is essential to ensure a return to normal functionality after fracture and to reduce the risk of later osteoarthritis.1 Surgical treatment of tibial plateau fractures typically involves anatomical reduction of the fracture, placement of autogenous bone grafts into any cancellous bone defects, and internal fixation.2 The filling of bone defects during tibial plateau fracture surgery is critical to ensure a satisfactory outcome.3 Although autologous bone grafting can be effective to this end,4 this approach is associated with several well-known problems, including donor site pain, infection, and morbidity. Hence, alternative materials have been investigated to fill bone defects in tibial plateau fracture repair. Alternatives include calcium sulfate, bone matrix gelatin, and hydroxyapatite, all of which differ in their size and morphology. Recently, a mixture of calcium sulfate hemihydrate and amorphous calcium phosphate has been shown to promote new bone formation.5 Supplementing this material with collagen shows promise as well.6 Bone matrix gelatin has been successfully used as a bone repair material in animal studies, in vitro experiments, and clinical case studies.7

Calcium phosphate cement (CPC), which has favorable physical and structural characteristics for use as a bone graft alternative,8 has been effectively used as a synthetic bone void filler in dental and orthopedic procedures for many years.9 Over the last decade, a number of clinical and cadaveric studies have examined the use of CPC to treat tibial plateau fractures. Findings from these studies generally suggest that CPC is an effective, or superior, substitute for autologous bone to treat tibial plateau fractures.2–4,10–14

No clinical study to date, however, has examined histological changes in bone following the use of CPC to treat tibial plateau fractures. Hence, the aim of this study was to examine histological changes in bone morphology after tibial plateau fracture repair using CPC. Bone tissue sample were obtained from the fracture site at the time of fracture repair and thereafter at the same site during removal of the internal fixator. We also examined bone healing, through radiographic imaging, and functional recovery.

sec.title: Study design and patients
sec.p: This was a retrospective case analysis study involving 42 patients with tibial plateau fractures who were treated at Minhang Central Hospital (affiliated with Shanghai Jiao Tong University) between January 2006 and May 2010. Inclusion criteria for surgery were unstable fracture, poor joint alignment, and more than 5 mm of articular surface collapse. If there was a residual cavity remaining after articular surface collapse, tricalcium phosphate was applied as a bone graft substitute when appropriate. Treatment involved bone grafting with CPC and internal fixation for all 42 patients. A further 34 patients with tibial plateau fractures who received articular surface restoration and internal fixation only were included as a control group. The diagnosis of tibial plateau fracture was made with reference to plain radiographs of the knee. Because of the specificity of the orthopedic surgery, economic factors may also influence the selection of treatment methods besides the individual differences. Therefore, patients who agreed to undergo bone grafting were included in the experimental group, and those who rejected bone grafting were included in the control group. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of our hospital, and patients provided written, informed consent to participate. Bone tissue was harvested only from patients who agreed to histological examination.

sec.title: Surgical procedures
sec.p: Knee joint X-rays were obtained before surgery to assess the degree of articular surface collapse. Additional computed tomographic scanning and subsequent 3-dimensional image reconstruction were performed to more precisely determine the severity of fracture comminution and articular collapse and to aid surgical planning.

A lateral parapatellar approach was used for surgery. An incision was made from a point 3 cm proximal to the distal end of the patella and distally extended over the inferior margin of the fracture site. A percutaneous insertion approach with a proximal incision was made superior to the lateral plateau and extended over the fracture site to expose the tibial plateau and the proximal part of the tibia. This facilitated convenient fracture reduction by leverage. A distal incision was made according to the length of the plate. A cortical bone window was made under the collapsed area and a periosteal elevator was inserted below the articular fracture fragment at the site of collapse. A few cancellous bone fragments were harvested for histological examination. The articular fracture fragment was elevated slowly and carefully and the cancellous bone was pressed together to form a large bone fragment. The bone fragment was further elevated to form a flat articular surface. At this point, the fracture fragment was temporarily fixed using K-wire or clamped. The cavity formed in the metaphysis was filled with porous CPC (Shanghai Bio-Lu Biomaterials Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China). A cancellous lag screw was then inserted for fixation of the reduced fragment and tibial plate(s) placed as necessary.

For patients with Schatzker type I to III fractures, plates were positioned on the lateral side of distal tibia, whereas plates were positioned on the medial side for patients with Schatzker type IV fractures (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Preoperative and postoperative radiographs (X-ray computed tomography (CT)). The figures were obtained from a 59-year-old male who had Schatzker II tibial plateau fractures after a traffic accidence. The figures showed articular surface collapsing and the outcome of articular surface restoration and bone grafting with CPC. (A) and (B): Anteroposterior and lateral X-ray photograph before fixation; (C) CT scan before fixation; (D) & (E): Anteroposterior and lateral X-ray after surgery; (F) CT scan after surgery.

sec.title: Postoperative care
sec.p: Antibiotics were routinely given for the first 24 h after surgery for closed fractures and for the first 48 to 72 h after surgery for open fractures. A plaster cast or brace was used for external fixation. Dressings were regularly changed and wound healing was monitored. If wound healing was satisfactory in 3 to 4 days after surgery, the external fixator was removed. During the secondary surgery to remove the internal fixator, a few cancellous bone fragments in the bone graft area were harvested for additional histological examination. The patient was instructed to begin quadriceps contraction and relaxation exercises and slight active motion. Early knee joint exercise was carried out using a continuous passive motion device. Weight-bearing activities were prohibited for the first 3 months after surgery. Patients were allowed to begin partial weight-bearing exercises, according to the state of bone healing, 12 to 16 weeks after surgery. Patients were instructed not to engage in heavy manual labour in full weight-bearing within the first 6 months of surgery.

sec.title: Outcome measures
sec.p: Regular follow-up was carried out for patients to observe the postoperative clinical outcomes using X-ray, Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS) score, and SF-36 score.

sec.title: Bone healing and functional recovery
sec.p: Postoperative follow-up examinations were performed at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after surgery to evaluate bone healing and functional recovery.

Bone healing was rated using the following criteria:
+: Periosteal reaction is evident, with patchy callus.
++: Callus is extended, forming a bridge with the connection between the new periosteal bone superior and inferior to the fracture line.
+++: Callus is connected with the fracture site, the boundary is smooth, the density is high but uneven, and there is no bone lamella.
++++: Periosteal reaction has subsided, the callus is small and absorbed, the density is even, and there are bone lamella and cortical bone connections.
Bone healing was not assessed for patients in the control group.

Functional recovery was evaluated by determining the HSS knee score 12 months after surgery.15 This score considers knee pain, function, activity, muscle power, flexion deformity, stability, brace usage, extension, and the presence of valgus and varus deformities. The maximum HSS knee score is 100 points, with a score of ≥85 indicating excellent function, a score of 70 to 84 points indicating good function, a score of 60 to 69 points indicating fair function, and a score of <60 points indicating poor function.

sec.title: Histological changes in bone morphology
sec.p: The clinical and histological differences for the group with bone grafting and the group without bone grafting were compared according to the results of histological examination of the bone tissue obtained during the initial surgery and during the surgery to remove the internal fixators. These samples were fixed in 10% formalin, decalcified, dehydrated, and embedded in paraffin. Longitudinal sections (0.1 µm) were cut and stained with hematoxylin and eosin. These sections were then examined using an optical microscope (model PMLS, Leica Microsystems GmbH, Wetzlar, Germany). A total of 10 fields were randomly selected and the number of inner bone cells in the bone matrix (850 µm × 850 µm area) was counted. Bone tissue samples were not obtained from patients in the control group due to the ethical consideration.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Continuous data are presented as means ± standard deviation. Between-group comparisons were made using independent two sample t-tests. Assessments made at initial surgery and at follow-up surgery to remove internal fixators were compared. Categorical data are presented as counts and percentages. Between-group comparisons for nominal data were made using Fisher’s exact test, whereas ordinal data were compared using Mann-Whitney test. The repeated measures of bone healing after surgery were compared by using Friedman’s test and Wilcoxon Signed Rank test (post-hoc). Spearman correlation coefficients (ρ) were determined to evaluate the relationships between both Schatzker classification type and age and postoperative outcomes (ρ ≤ 0.3 indicated low correlation; 0.3 < ρ ≤ 0.7 indicated moderate correlation; ρ ≥ 0.7 indicated high correlation). All statistical assessments were two-sided with a significance level of p < 0.05. Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 15.0 statistical software (SPSS Institute Inc., Chicago, IL).

sec.title: Bone healing and resorption of CPC
sec.p:
Bone healing scores significantly improved with time after surgery (p < 0.001; Figure 2). At 3 months after surgery, 66.7% of patients were classified as having + bone healing, while 33.3% were classified as having ++ bone healing. Nine months later (i.e., 12 months after surgery), 73.8% of patients were classified as having ++++ bone healing, while the remaining 26.2% were classified as having +++ bone healing. Figure 2.
Bone healing scores after tibial plateau fracture surgery involving open reduction, use of calcium phosphate cement, and internal fixation. Bone healing scores significantly improved with time (p < 0.001). +: Periosteal reaction was evident, with patchy callus; ++: Callus was extended, forming a bridge with the connection between the new periosteal bone superior and inferior to the fracture line; +++: Callus was connected with the fracture site, the boundary was smooth, density was high but uneven, and there were no bone lamellae; ++++: Periosteal reaction had subsided, the callus was small and absorbed, density was even, and there were bone lamellae and cortical bone connections.

Postoperative radiography revealed varying degrees of CPC resorption 1 to 3 months after surgery and the appearance of callus at the fracture site. More comprehensive CPC resorption was evident in all cases 3 to 9 months after surgery. Resorption of CPC was complete in 9 to 12 months after surgery.

sec.title: Functional recovery
sec.p:
Mean HSS knee scores were not statistically different between the CPC and control groups 12 months after surgery (Figure 3). Mean knee function was “good” (HSS knee score of 70 to 84 points) in both groups. Figure 3.
Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS) knee scores in the calcium phosphate cement (CPC) and control groups 12 months after tibial plateau fracture treatment with open reduction, use of CPC, and internal fixation (CPC group) or open reduction and internal fixation (control group). No significant difference between the two groups was observed (82.3 vs. 79.4, p = 0.263).

sec.title: Schatzker type versus efficacy end points
sec.p: In group I, Schatzker type versus bone healing score at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months at post-surgery were moderately correlated. Those with worse Schatzker type were more likely to have worse bone healing score, with Spearman correlation coefficients of −0.530, −0.688, −0.648, −0.606, respectively (all p < 0.001). No significant correlation was observed between Schatzker type or post-surgery HSS knee score with bone cell counts. In group II, Schatzker type versus HSS knee scores at post-surgery were moderately correlated. Those with worse Schatzker type were more likely to have worse HSS knee score at post-surgery, with negative Spearman correlation coefficients of −0.614 (p < 0.001).

sec.title: Age versus efficacy end points
sec.p: In group I, moderate correlation were observed in age versus bone healing score at 3, 6, and 9 months but not observed in age versus bone healing score at 12 months. The Spearman correlation coefficients were −0.440 (p = 0.004), −0.346 (p = 0.025), and −0.317 (p = 0.041). The results indicate the older patients in group I had worse bone healing within 9 months at post-surgery. Age was correlated to HSS knee score, with older patients in group I having worse HSS knee score at post surgery, with a moderate Spearman correlation coefficient of −0.338 (p = 0.028). In addition, moderate correlation was observed between age and bone cell count at first and second surgery. The older patients in group I were more likely to have lower bone cell counts, with Spearman correlation coefficients of −0.608 (p < 0.001) and −0.490 (p = 0.007), respectively, for older and younger patients. However, no similar result was observed in group II, that is, no significant correlation of age with HSS knee score.

sec.title: Histological changes in bone morphology
sec.p:
Bone cell counts from bone samples were significantly higher in those from the second surgery (removal of internal fixators) than those from the first surgery (open reduction, use of CPC, and internal fixation; p < 0.001; Figure 4). Figure 4.
Total bone cell counts at the fracture site during the first surgery and at the same site during the second surgery. The mean bone cell count was significantly increased at the second surgery compared with the first surgery (p < 0.001).

Bone samples from the first surgery exhibited fragmented bone tissue, degenerated bone cells, disordered bone matrix, marked by broken trabeculae, intramedullary congestion, and edema (Figure 5(A)). The cavity formed in the metaphysis was filled with porous CPC (Figure 5(B)). Bone samples obtained from the second surgery (removal of internal fixator) exhibited actively proliferating osteoblasts in new bone tissue, differentiated and mature bone cells with increased density, neatly arranged bone matrix, trabeculae with increased density and fibrous tissue and capillary proliferation between them, and thickened vessels between the periosteum trabecula (Figure 5(C)). Moreover, there was evidence of bone marrow cavity formation containing many lipid and red blood cells, suggesting active new bone production and proliferation. Lumen formation was evident in tissue, with a preponderance of red blood cells and osteoblasts, indicating active proliferation of new bone. New vessels, red blood cells, and bone cells could be seen in bone tissue from the graft, indicating excellent bone growth in this area (Figure 6). Figure 5.

(A) Fragmented bone tissue, degenerated bone cells (arrow), disordered bone matrix, broken trabecula, intramedullary congestion, and edema were apparent for samples obtained during the first surgery involving open reduction, use of calcium phosphate cement, and internal fixation (Magnification = ×40). (B) The cavity formed in the metaphysis was filled with porous CPC. (C) Active proliferation of osteoblasts, differentiation, and maturation of bone cells with increased density, neatly arranged bone matrix, numerous trabeculae with increased density, thickened vessels between the periosteum and trabecula, and fibrous tissue and capillary proliferation between the trabeculae were apparent for samples obtained during the second surgery involving removal of internal fixators.

sec.title: Postoperative pain and complications
sec.p: Joint pain gradually decreased with time after surgery as determined during follow-up visits. Joint stability and activity levels gradually improved with time after surgery to normal levels. There were no instances of further collapse or infection in the CPC group. One patient in the CPC group experienced wound oozing on the second day after the first surgical procedure. Bacterial culture of the wound fluid was negative. This patient received local treatment and wound healing was apparent 1 week later. One patient in the control group experienced recurrent tibial plateau collapse after the first surgical procedure.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This is a clinical study to examine histological changes at the site of tibial plateau fracture after fracture repair involving open reduction and internal fixation, using CPC as a substitute for autologous bone to fill bone defects. We observed histological evidence of bone healing in patients who received CPC as indicated by well-arranged trabeculae, new bone and blood vessel formation, and significantly increased bone cell counts. Importantly, radiographic assessment indicated significantly improved bone healing with time after surgery and functional recovery was graded “good” in 12 months after surgery.

Although no previous clinical studies have been reported to examine histological changes following tibial plateau fracture repair involving the use of CPC, several comparable animal studies have been performed. Consistent with our findings in humans, Frankenburg and his colleagues observed new bone and small blood vessel formation in dogs in which CPC was placed in proximal tibial and femoral metaphyseal defects.8 Furthermore, CPC was found to exhibit properties comparable to normal cancellous bone. This vascularization in the area of CPC placement is particularly critical for osteogenesis and bone healing and is thus an important characteristic of CPC. Also consistent with our findings, Nandi and colleagues reported the presence of bone marrow material, lipid cells, and blood vessels in histological sections obtained from sites of radial diaphyseal bone defects filled with CPC in goats.16

In keeping with the histological evidence of bone healing, we also observed radiological evidence of bone healing after use of CPC to treat tibial plateau fractures, which increased with time after surgery. Specifically, bone healing was rated as ++++ (73.8%) or +++ (26.2%) in all patients 12 months after surgery. These findings are consistent with those reported in similar clinical studies examining the use of CPC to treat tibial plateau fractures, in which the majority (≥ 93%) of patients exhibited excellent to good Rasmussen radiological scores.3,4,13 Also consistent with these studies, we observed that resorption of CPC was complete within 9 to 12 months after surgery.

To our knowledge, only one study in the literature has examined functional outcomes by assessing HSS knee scores after the use of CPC to treat tibial plateau fractures. In our study, the mean HSS knee score 12 months after surgery was 82.3 (indicating “good” function), whereas the mean HSS knee scores were 91.8, 82.7, and 78.2 for Schatzker type II (n = 73), V (n = 34), and VI (n = 17) fractures in the study performed by Shen and colleagues.4 Hence, the mean overall score was higher in the study performed by Shen and colleagues,4 perhaps reflecting the slightly different distribution of fracture types between studies. Several other studies have examined knee function by assessing Lysholm knee scores after the use of CPC to treat tibial plateau fractures and reported good to excellent outcomes in the majority (≥81%) of patients.3,13

This study is limited by the lack of control data for the histological and radiological findings. Clearly, the optimal control for a study of this nature would have been patients undergoing the same procedures but having autologous bone grafting, rather than CPC, to fill bone defects. Hence, we cannot comment on the relative bone healing of autologous bone grafting. Nevertheless, we believe that our findings, which demonstrated definite histological evidence of bone healing following use of CPC in tibial plateau fracture repair, are relevant and of interest. Certainly, a direct histological comparison of outcomes between approaches (CPC vs autologous bone) would be of significant interest.
In conclusion, the histological, radiological, and functional findings suggest that CPC may be an effective substitute for autologous bone grafting to trea tibial plateau fractures.
